case_name: Appellants v. State of Jammu and Kashmir

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 152 of 1955 arises from a suit filed by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises from a suit filed by the appellant in a representative capacity  Civil Suit No. 4 of 2008  against the State of Jammu Kashmir

facts.text: Appellant filed Civil Suit No. 4 of 2008 against State of Jammu and Kashmir for declaration that Jammu and Kashmir Big Landed Estate Abolition Act, XVII of 2007 is void.

anchor.surface_text: against the State of Jammu Kashmir praying for a declaration that the Jammu Kashmir Big Landed Estate Abolition Act, XVII of 2007  hereinafter called the Act  is void, inoperative and ultra vires of Yuvaraj Karan Singh

facts.text: Maghar Singh filed Civil Suit No. 59 of 2007 challenging validity of the Act, dismissed by Mr. Justice Kilam who held the Act valid.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the validity of the Act was similarly challenged by Maghar Singh by his suit filed on the Original Side of the High Court of Jammu Kashmir  Civil Suit No. 59 of 2007  and Mr. Justice Kilam who had heard the said suit had rejected the plaintiffs companytentions and held that the Act was valid.

facts.text: Appellant's suit before District Court conceded points decided by Justice Kilam, suit dismissed holding Act valid.

anchor.surface_text: When the appellant suit came for trial before the District Court it was companyceded on his behalf that the points raised by him against the validity of the Act had been decided by Mr. Justice Kilam and that, in view of the said decision, the appellant companyld number usefully urge anything more before the District Court.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to High Court in Civil Appeal No. 4 of 2009, dismissed along with Maghar Singh's appeal No. 29 of 2008 on March 25, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decree the appellant preferred an appeal in the High Court of Jammu Kashmir  Civil Appeal No. 4 of 2009 . Maghar Singh whose suit had been dismissed by Mr. Justice Kilam had also preferred an appeal  No. 29 of 2008  before the High Court.

facts.text: High Court Division Bench held Act valid and dismissed appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The two appeals were heard together by a -Division Bench of the High Court which held that the Act was valid and that the appellants were number entitled to any declaration claimed by them. Both the appeals were accordingly dismissed.

facts.text: Special leave to appeal to Supreme Court granted after High Court refused leave.

anchor.surface_text: Against the decree passed by the High Court dismissing his appeal the appellant applied to the High Court for leave to appeal to this Court. The said application was, however, dismissed. Thereupon the appellant applied for, and obtained, special leave to appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Maharaja Hari Singh succeeded Maharaja Pratap Singh as Ruler of Kashmir in 1925.

anchor.surface_text: In 1925 Maharaja Hari Singh succeeded Maharaja Pratap Singh as the Ruler of Kashmir.

facts.text: Maharaja Hari Singh issued Regulation 1 of 1991 (1934) providing for association of subjects in legislation and administration.

anchor.surface_text: Presumably as a sequel to the said agitation Maharaja Hari Singh issued Regulation 1 of 1991  1934 . The -Regulation began with the statement of policy that it was the declared intention of the Maharaja to provide for the association of his subjects

facts.text: Maharaja promulgated Jammu and Kashmir Constitution Act 14 of 1996 (1939).

anchor.surface_text: Five years later the Maharaja promulgated the Jammu Kashmir Constitution Act 14 of 1996  1939 .

facts.text: Indian Independence Act, 1947 passed, suzerainty lapsed.

anchor.surface_text: While the State of Jammu Kashmir was being governed by the Maharaja and the second Constitution as amended from time to time was in operation, political events were moving very fast in India and they culminated in the passing of the Indian Independence Act, 1947.

facts.text: Tribal raiders invaded State on October 22, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: On October 22, 1947, the tribal raiders invaded the territory of the State

facts.text: Maharaja signed Instrument of Accession with India on October 25, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: On October 25, 1947, the Maharaja signed an Instrument of Accession with India which had then become an Independent Dominion.

facts.text: Maharaja issued proclamation on March 5, 1948 setting up popular interim government.

anchor.surface_text: The Maharaja tried to pacify the popular demand by issuing a proclamation on March 5, 1948.

facts.text: Maharaja issued proclamation on June 20, 1949 entrusting all powers to Yuvaraj Karan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: When the atmosphere in the State was thus surcharged, the Maharaja issued his final proclamation on June 20, 1949, by which he entrusted to Yuvaraj Karan Singh Bahadur all his powers and functions

facts.text: Yuvaraj Karan Singh issued proclamation on November 25, 1949 applying Constitution of India as applicable.

anchor.surface_text: On November 25, 1949, Yuvaraj Karan Singh issued a proclamation by which he declared and directed that the Constitution of India shortly to be adopted

facts.text: Constitution of India came into force on January 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On January 26, 1950, the Constitution of India came into force.

facts.text: Jammu and Kashmir Big Landed Estate Abolition Act promulgated by Yuvaraj Karan Singh on October 17, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It was presumably in pursuance of this plan adopted by the interim Cabinet that the Act was promulgated by Yuvaraj Karan Singh on October 17, 1950.

facts.text: Act enacted in exercise of powers under Constitution Act of 1996 and Maharaja's proclamation of June 20, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The Yuvaraj enacted the law in exercise of the -powers vested in him under s. of the. Constitution Act of 1996 and theproclamation issued by Maharaja Hari Singh on June 20, 1949.

facts.text: Section 4(1) of Act extinguishes proprietor's right of ownership in land other than specified, from date Act comes into force.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4, sub-s.  1  provides for the extinction of the right of ownership in certain lands and it lays down that number withstanding anything companytained in any law for the time being in force, the right of ownership held by a proprietor in land other than the land mentioned in sub-s.  2  shall

facts.text: Section 26 provides for annuity to expropriated proprietors until Constituent Assembly settles compensation.

anchor.surface_text: Section 26 of the Act deals with the question of payment to the proprietors. It provides that there shall, until the Constituent Assembly of the State settles the question of companypensation

facts.text: Yuvaraj issued proclamation on April 20, 1951 for Constituent Assembly.

anchor.surface_text: After the Act was enacted by the yuvaraj he issued a proclamation on April 20, 1951, directing that a Constituent Assembly companysisting of representatives of the people elected on the basis of adult franchise

facts.text: Constituent Assembly framed Constitution, abolished hereditary rule, elected Yuvaraj as Sadar-i-Riyasat on November 13, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with this proclamation a Constituent Assembly was elected and it framed the Constitution for the State. By the Constitution thus framed the hereditary rule of the State was abolished, and a provision was made for the election of a Sadar-i-Riyasat

facts.text: Court held Yuvaraj Karan Singh competent to enact the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that Yuvaraj Karan Singh was companypetent to enact the Act in 1950 and so the challenge to the validity of the Act on the ground that he did number possess legislative companypetence in that behalf cannot succeed.

facts.text: Court held Act provides for compensation via s.26 and no Art.31 limitation applied then.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that the validity of the Act cannot be chal- lenged on the ground that the Act did number provide for the payment of companypensation. For one thing s. 26 of the Act did companytemplate the payment of companypensation.

holdings.text: Yuvaraj Karan Singh was competent to enact the Jammu and Kashmir Big Landed Estate Abolition Act in 1950.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Maharaja was absolute monarch with plenary powers preserved in Regulation 1934 s.3 and Constitution Act 1939 ss.4-5; lapsed paramountcy confirmed sovereignty; full delegation via June 20, 1949 proclamation; unaffected by Nov 25, 1949 proclamation or Art.370.

holdings.text: Maharaja Hari Singh remained an absolute monarch post-Indian Independence Act 1947 and Instrument of Accession.

anchor.surface_text: Whilst this was the true constitutional position the Independence Act, 1947, was passed by the British Parliament and with the lapse of the British paramountcy the Rulers of Indian States

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.7 Indian Independence Act lapsed paramountcy; cl.8 Instrument of Accession preserved sovereignty; state constitutions explicitly retained all inherent powers.

holdings.text: Maharaja's June 20, 1949 proclamation fully delegated all powers to Yuvaraj Karan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that, during the temporary period that the Maharaja wanted to leave the State for reasons of health, he conferred on Yuvaraj Karan Singh all his powers and functions

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absolute monarch can delegate all powers without limitation, analogous to sovereign legislature (citing Delhi Laws Act).

holdings.text: Yuvaraj's November 25, 1949 proclamation did not limit his powers.

anchor.surface_text: The next contention is that the powers of Yuvaraj Karan Singh were substantially limited by the proclamation issued by him on November 25, 1949. We are not impressed even by this argument.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mirrors Instrument of Accession; affects only Union-State relations, not internal sovereignty.

holdings.text: Application of Art.370 and specified Constitution articles did not extinguish Yuvaraj's sovereignty or plenary legislative powers.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee, however, has very seriously pressed before us his contention that, as a result of the application of certain specified articles of the Constitution to the State of Jammu Kashm

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.370 temporary, limited to Union-State relations; no Legislative Lists applied; state plenary powers preserved; purposive interpretation in context of accession.

holdings.text: Act valid regarding compensation; s.26 contemplates payment, Art.31 not applicable at enactment.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that the validity of the Act cannot be challenged on the ground that the Act did not provide for the payment of compensation. For one thing s. 26 of the Act did contemplate the

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.26 provides annuity pending Constituent Assembly; no constitutional limitation like Art.31 applied to state then.

holdings.text: Constituent Assembly properly constituted and its decision on compensation valid.

anchor.surface_text: There is another aspect of the matter to which reference must be made. Section 26 of the Act had left the final decision on the question of the payment of compensation to the Constituent A

holdings.reasoning_summary: Yuvaraj competent to issue April 20, 1951 proclamation convening Assembly on adult franchise.

holdings.text: Act not invalid under Art.254 due to inconsistency with prior laws.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent List not extended to state; no repugnancy determinable under Art.254(1); cl.(2) inapplicable.

holdings.text: All challenges to Act's validity fail; Act is valid and not ultra vires.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative rejection of all petitioner arguments upholds lower courts.

precedents.citation: Attorney- General v. De Keysers Royal Hotel Ltd.  2  1920 A.C. 508, 526

anchor.surface_text: This observation has been cited with approval by the House of Lords in the case of Attorney- General v. De Keysers Royal Hotel Ltd.  2 . We do number see how this statement can assist us in determining the companystitutional status, and the extent of the powers, of Maharaja Hari Singh in relation to the governance of the State. The said discussion in Diceys treatise has reference to the special features of the history of English companystitutional development and it would naturally be of numberrelevance in dealing with the effect of the Constitution of 1996 with which we are companycerned.

precedents.case_name: Attorney-General v. De Keyser's Royal Hotel Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Approval of Dicey's observation that the prerogative is the residue of discretionary or arbitrary authority left in the hands of the Crown

anchor.surface_text: As Chief Justice Kania has observed in Re Delhi Laws Act, 1912  1  A legislative body which is sovereign like an autocratic Ruler has power to do anything. It may, like a Ruler, by an individual decision, direct that a certain person may be put to death or a certain property may be taken over by the State. A body of such character may have power to numberinate someone who can exercise all its powers and make all its decisions.

precedents.cited_proposition: A sovereign legislature or autocratic ruler possesses absolute power to delegate all legislative, executive, and judicial powers to another person or body without limitation or judicial review
precedents.cited_holding: A legislative body which is sovereign like an autocratic Ruler has power to do anything... there is no authority or tribunal which can question the right or power of the authority to do so

justification_sets.label: Section 4 J&K Big Landed Estates Abolition Act XVII 2007 (1950) support

anchor.surface_text: The result is that all the grounds urged by the appellant against the validity of the Act fail, and so it must be held that the High Court was right in taking the view that the plaintiff had number shown that the Act was ultra vires.

outcome.relief_summary: All grounds challenging validity of the Jammu Kashmir Big Landed Estate Abolition Act rejected; High Court decision upheld
